description:
Please make the following changes, where possible, to the home page.

Here’s what I’d do next.

First, the copy is basically done. The H1 is tight, outcome-focused, and specific. The subheadline is excellent—technical enough to signal competence, plain enough for business owners. Don’t keep iterating copy unless you’re A/B testing.

Now the improvements.

1. The hero still lacks a focal artifact
You’ve added texture (nice skyline + radial gradient), but there’s nothing that visually proves “this person builds modern websites.”

One strong move:
Add a single, understated browser mockup (right side or slightly offset) showing a real project or tasteful fake. Even blurred content works. It instantly reframes you from “marketing site” to “builder.”

This is the single biggest visual upgrade you can make.

2. CTA hierarchy is good, but spacing can do more work
The buttons are right, but they’re floating in empty space.

Consider:

Slightly more vertical separation between copy block and CTAs

Or a faint container / glow behind the primary CTA only

This increases perceived clickability without louder colors.

3. The “Built by a senior web developer…” line is gold—surface it more
That sentence is doing heavy lifting, but it’s visually quiet.

Options:

Add a small icon (checkmark / bolt / code glyph)

Increase font weight slightly

Split it into two lines for scannability

This is your differentiation vs agencies and Wix freelancers—don’t hide it.

4. The Houston footer tag is clever, but too subtle
The coordinates + “Serving the Greater Houston Area” is a nice touch, but right now it feels like an Easter egg.

I’d either:

Increase contrast just a bit

Or move it slightly higher so it reads as intentional, not decorative

You want users to notice it subconsciously.

5. Add one micro-interaction
Right now it’s static. One motion cue will bring it to life:

Very slow gradient drift

Fade/slide-in on first load (headline → sub → CTA)

Subtle hover animation on primary CTA

One. Not three. This is about polish, not flair.

6. One optional but powerful trust nudge
If you have anything factual:

“10+ years experience”

“Built X+ production sites”

“React / TypeScript specialist”

Put it in tiny text near the CTAs. Even vague-but-true beats silence.
title: Update home page hero with visual artifact and micro-interactions
